paragraphs.zh-tw: I have a confession to make. As a scientist and engineer,I've focused on efficiency for many years. But efficiency can be a cult, and today I'd like to tell youabout a journey that moved me out of the cultand back to a far richer reality.
paragraphs.en: 我想要向各位懺悔 作爲一名科學家與工程師，多年來我專注於提高效率 有時效率會變成一種迷信 今天，我想與你們分享一段奇遇 這段奇遇把我從對效率的迷信中解救出來 帶我回到了更豐富的現實世界

paragraphs.zh-tw: A few years ago, after finishing my Ph.D. in London, I moved to Boston. I lived in Boston and worked in Cambridge.
paragraphs.en: 幾年前，我在倫敦博士畢業後，來到波士頓 我在波士頓居住，在劍橋工作

paragraphs.zh-tw: I bought a racing bicycle that summer, and I bicycled every day to work. To find my way, I used my phone.
paragraphs.en: 在那一年的夏天，我買了一輛競賽型腳踏車 每天我都騎腳踏車去工作 我用手機導航找路

paragraphs.zh-tw: It sent me over Mass. Ave.,Massachusetts Avenue, the shortest route fromBoston to Cambridge. But after a month that I was cycling every dayon the car-packed Mass. Ave., I took a different route one day.
paragraphs.en: 通過導航，我會經過馬薩大道即馬薩諸塞州大道 這是從波士頓前往劍橋的最短路徑 然而，一個月後的某一天 在經曆了馬薩大道上的厮殺後 我決定騎另一條路線

paragraphs.zh-tw: I'm not entirely sure why I tooka different route that day, a detour. I just remember a feeling of surprise; surprise at finding a street with no cars, as opposed to the nearbyMass. Ave. full of cars; surprise at finding a street draped by leaves and surrounded by trees.
paragraphs.en: 我並不是十分確定爲什麽當時我會選擇另一條路線 我只記得，我的心裡十分驚喜 驚喜這是一條沒有車輛的路 因為隔壁的馬薩大道擠滿了車 驚喜這是一條被大樹圍繞，被落葉鋪蓋的路

paragraphs.zh-tw: But after the feeling of surprise, I felt shame. How could I have been so blind? For an entire month, I was so trapped in my mobile app that a journey to workbecame one thing only: the shortest path.
paragraphs.en: 可是，驚喜之餘，我感到了羞愧 我怎麽會如此的盲目？ 過去整整一個月 我都被困在了手機的導航應用裡 騎腳踏車去工作的路僅僅意味著： 這是一條最短的路

paragraphs.zh-tw: In this single journey,there was no thought of enjoying the road, no pleasure in connecting with nature, no possibility of lookingpeople in the eyes. And why? Because I was saving a minuteout of my commute.
paragraphs.en: 在這段單調的路途中 完全沒有享受這條路的愉悅 也沒有與大自然交流的樂趣 在路上，我根本不可能去看其他路人 爲什麽？ 因爲我想盡量減少上下班花費的時間，哪怕只是一分鍾

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now let me ask you: Am I alone here? How many of you have never useda mapping app for finding directions? Most of you, if not all, have. And don't get me wrong -- mapping appsare the greatest game-changer for encouraging peopleto explore the city.
paragraphs.en: 現在讓我問一個問題：我是在場唯一經曆過此事的人嗎？ 有多少人從沒用過導航應用來確定方向？ 絕大多數的人都曾用過導航 也千萬別誤會我的意思導航的確也是改變社會的一大應用 它鼓勵人們去探索他們的城市

paragraphs.zh-tw: You take your phone outand you know immediately where to go. However, the app also assumes there are only a handfulof directions to the destination.
paragraphs.en: 你拿出你的手機，不出幾秒，你就知道你要去哪兒了 可是，應用只能提供 幾條有限的路線

paragraphs.zh-tw: It has the power to makethose handful of directions the definitive directionto that destination. After that experience, I changed.
paragraphs.en: 導航把這幾條路線 變成成爲到達目的地的唯一選擇 在那段經曆過後，我做出了改變

paragraphs.zh-tw: I changed my researchfrom traditional data-mining to understanding how peopleexperience the city. I used computer science tools to replicate social scienceexperiments at scale, at web scale.
paragraphs.en: 我把我的研究方向從傳統的數據挖掘 改爲理解人們的城市體驗 我通過電腦科技 完成社會實驗，並把社會實驗帶入網路

paragraphs.zh-tw: I became captivatedby the beauty and genius of traditional social science experiments done by Jane Jacobs,Stanley Milgram, Kevin Lynch. The result of that researchhas been the creation of new maps, maps where you don't only findthe shortest path, the blue one, but also the most enjoyable path, the red one.
paragraphs.en: 在此其中， 我被這些實驗中暗含的的美妙與真理深深迷住 特別是由 Jane Jacobs, Stanley Milgram和 Kevin Lynch 完成的 傳統的社會科學實驗 這個研究的成果是一張新的地圖 在這張地圖裡，你不僅僅能找到最短的路線，即藍色的那條 還能找到最令人享受的路線 就是這條紅色的路線

paragraphs.zh-tw: How was that possible? Einstein once said, "Logic will get you from A to B. Imagination will take you everywhere." So with a bit of imagination, we needed to understand which parts of the citypeople find beautiful.
paragraphs.en: 這到底是怎麽做到的呢？ 愛因斯坦曾經說過 “邏輯能讓你從A點到達B點。 而想像力，卻能讓你到達所有地方。” 因此，通過一點點的想像力 我們找到了 城市哪個部分讓人們覺得很美

paragraphs.zh-tw: At the University of Cambridge,with colleagues, we thought about this simple experiment. If I were to show youthese two urban scenes, and I were to ask youwhich one is more beautiful, which one would you say? Don't be shy.
paragraphs.en: 我和在劍橋大學的時的同事們 想出一個簡單的實驗 如果我向你展示兩張城市的景色圖片 並問你哪一張最漂亮 你會選哪一個呢? 別害羞

paragraphs.zh-tw: Who says A? Who says B? Brilliant. Based on that idea, we built a crowdsourcing platform, a web game.
paragraphs.en: 誰選A？ 誰選B？ 好極了 基於這個想法 我們建立了一個利用群衆資源的平台 一個線上遊戲

paragraphs.zh-tw: Players are shown pairs of urban scenes, and they're asked to choose which one is more beautiful, quiet and happy. Based on thousands of user votes, then we are able to seewhere consensus emerges.
paragraphs.en: 在遊戲中，我們會展示給玩家們成對的城市景色 並讓他們選擇哪一個景色更美麗，更安靜，更有幸福感 基於上千張的用戶投票 我們能夠得出哪裡有公認的美景

paragraphs.zh-tw: We are able to see whichare the urban scenes that make people happy. After that work, I joined Yahoo Labs, and I teamed up with Luca and Rossano, and together, we aggregatedthose winning locations in London to build a new map of the city, a cartography weighted for human emotions.
paragraphs.en: 哪裡是公認 能讓路人感到幸福的景色 在那次實驗之後，我加入了雅虎實驗室 我與 Luca 和 Rossano 組隊 收集那些在倫敦勝出的景色 利用這些數據，我們制定了一張新地圖 這張地圖以感受做為基礎

paragraphs.zh-tw: On this cartography, you're not onlyable to see and connect from point A to point B the shortest segments, but you're also ableto see the happy segment, the beautiful path, the quiet path. In tests, participants found the happy,the beautiful, the quiet path far more enjoyable than the shortest one, and that just by addinga few minutes to travel time.
paragraphs.en: 在地圖裡，你不僅僅能看見並連接 A點和B點，了解到最近的路線 你還能看到快樂的路線 美麗的路線，和安靜的路線 在地圖測試中，參與者們發現那些快樂、美麗、安靜的路線 都遠比最短的路線更令人享受 而且那些路線所花的時間只是多了幾分鍾

paragraphs.zh-tw: Participants also love to attachmemories to places. Shared memories --that's where the old BBC building was; and personal memories --that's where I gave my first kiss.
paragraphs.en: 參與者們也很喜歡把回憶注入到這些景色中 其中有大衆的回憶這是BBC的舊址 也有私人的回憶那是我獻出初吻的地方

paragraphs.zh-tw: They also recalled how some pathssmelled and sounded. So what if we had a mapping tool that would returnthe most enjoyable routes based not only on aesthetics but also based on smell, sound, and memories? That's where our researchis going right now.
paragraphs.en: 他們都回憶起這些道路曾經的味道與聲音 我們便有了這樣一個地圖應用 它指出的路線 並不僅僅基於美觀， 而是建立在氣味、聲音與回憶上 這便是我們現在研究的目標

paragraphs.zh-tw: More generally, my research, what it tries to do is avoidthe danger of the single path, to avoid robbing people of fullyexperiencing the city in which they live. Walk the path through the park,not through the car park, and you have an entirely different path.
paragraphs.en: 簡單地說，我的研究目標是 避免單一選項 讓使用者能真正地享受他們居住的城市 散步在公園小徑上而不是停車場 這條路就會變得截然不同

paragraphs.zh-tw: Walk the path full of people you love and not full of cars, and you have an entirely different path. It's that simple.
paragraphs.en: 與愛的回憶相伴 而不是與車輛爭道 這條路就變得截然不同 就這麽簡單

paragraphs.zh-tw: I would like to end with this thought: do you remember "The Truman Show?" It's a media satire in which a real person doesn't know he's livingin a fabricated world. Perhaps we live in a worldfabricated for efficiency.
paragraphs.en: 我希望用一個想法來結束這次演講： 你們還記得《楚門的世界》嗎？ 這部諷刺電影描述一個人 不知道他的世界是個人造的假象 或許我們就活在效率編織的假象裡

paragraphs.zh-tw: Look at some of your daily habits, and as Truman did in the movie,escape the fabricated world. Why? Well, if you think that adventureis dangerous, try routine. It's deadly.
paragraphs.en: 看看你們的日常習慣 快像電影裡的楚門一樣，逃出這個虛假的世界吧 爲什麽呢？ 好吧，如果你覺得冒險是危險的 那麽繼續走你致命的常規路線吧

paragraphs.zh-tw: Thank you.
paragraphs.en: 謝謝
